# The Evolution of Multimodal Models: From Early Visual Representations to Large Multimodal Language Models

## 1. Introduction

The development of multimodal artificial intelligence models represents one of the most significant advancements in modern machine learning, enabling systems to understand and generate content across multiple sensory modalities. Multimodal models, which integrate information from different data types such as text, images, audio, and video, have evolved dramatically over the past few decades, transforming from specialized systems for narrow tasks to general-purpose intelligent assistants capable of sophisticated cross-modal reasoning . This comprehensive survey explores the evolutionary path of multimodal models from their origins in early visual representations to the current state-of-the-art multimodal large language models (MLLMs), examining the key technological breakthroughs that have driven this transformation.

The human experience of the world is inherently multimodal—we perceive and understand the environment through the integration of visual, auditory, linguistic, and other sensory inputs. Replicating this capability in artificial systems has been a long-standing goal in artificial intelligence research. The evolution of multimodal models reflects broader trends in AI, including the shift from handcrafted features to learned representations, the rise of deep learning, and the development of increasingly powerful foundation models [(10)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.00389).

This paper is structured to provide a detailed account of this evolutionary journey. We begin by examining the early approaches to visual representation and multimodal learning, then trace the development of increasingly sophisticated models that combined vision and language. We explore the impact of large language models on multimodal research and discuss the current state of multimodal large language models. Finally, we outline the key technological breakthroughs that have defined each stage of this evolution and discuss future directions for the field.

## 2. Early Approaches to Visual Representation and Multimodal Learning

### 2.1 Pre-Deep Learning Era: Handcrafted Features and Modular Systems

Before the deep learning revolution, visual representation relied heavily on handcrafted features designed by human engineers. These features were based on specific characteristics of images, such as edges, textures, and shapes, and were typically extracted using algorithms that were manually designed rather than learned from data [(13)](https://www.techtarget.com/searchEnterpriseAI/definition/vision-language-models-VLMs).

Machine vision research dates back to the early 1970s when researchers began exploring various methods to extract edges, label lines, identify objects, or classify conditions in images [(13)](https://www.techtarget.com/searchEnterpriseAI/definition/vision-language-models-VLMs). Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, researchers investigated how scale space—a way of representing images at different levels of detail—could help align views of things across various scales. This led to the development of algorithms that could connect multiple levels of abstraction, which was particularly useful in domains like medicine for joining up imagery of cells, organs, and body parts [(13)](https://www.techtarget.com/searchEnterpriseAI/definition/vision-language-models-VLMs).

One of the earliest examples of multimodal research was audio-visual speech recognition (AVSR), which combined visual information from lip movements with auditory speech signals to improve recognition accuracy [(12)](https://www.twelvelabs.io/blog/what-is-multimodal-ai). Early AVSR models were based on hidden Markov models (HMMs), which were popular in the speech recognition community at the time. While AVSR research became less common for a time, it has seen renewed interest with the rise of deep learning [(12)](https://www.twelvelabs.io/blog/what-is-multimodal-ai).

In the pre-deep learning era, multimodal systems were typically modular, with separate components for processing each modality and explicit rules or algorithms for combining the results. These systems were often designed for specific tasks and lacked the flexibility to generalize to new domains or modalities [(10)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.00389).

### 2.2 Early Deep Learning Approaches to Multimodal Integration

The introduction of deep learning techniques marked a significant turning point in multimodal research. One of the earliest applications of deep learning to multimodal problems was in the area of cross-modality feature learning, where better features for one modality (e.g., video) could be learned when trained on data comprising two or more modalities (e.g., video and audio) . This idea was first introduced in 2011, marking the beginning of what would become a transformative approach to multimodal learning .

In the early 2010s, researchers began exploring the use of deep neural networks for multimodal learning tasks. One of the earliest and most influential approaches was the multimodal deep belief network (DBN), which allowed for better modeling of complex patterns from multiple input modalities in both supervised, semi-supervised, and unsupervised learning protocols . Despite their advantages, these models had limitations, including their tendency to ignore the spatiotemporal cues of multimodal data streams, which made the inference process computationally intensive .

Another significant development during this period was the application of deep learning to visual-semantic embedding, where models learned to project images and text into a shared feature space. Kernel canonical correlation analysis (KCCA) was one of the earliest methods used to project image and sentence features into a common space by learning projections [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). Subsequent research attempted bidirectional mapping between images and text descriptions using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

However, RNNs were found to have weaknesses in remembering concepts, leading to the introduction of long short-term memory networks (LSTMs) to form CNN-LSTM combinations [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). The introduction of the attention mechanism significantly improved the capabilities of image-text multimodal models, allowing them to focus on relevant parts of the image when generating text descriptions or answering questions [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

Graphical descriptions based on CNNs and LSTMs could now be trained by maximizing an approximate variational lower bound or, equivalently, by reinforcement learning [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). These early deep learning approaches laid the foundation for more sophisticated multimodal models that would follow, setting the stage for the development of vision-language models that would become increasingly prominent in the years to come.

## 3. The Rise of Vision-Language Models

### 3.1 Early Vision-Language Models

The development of vision-language models (VLMs) represented a significant advancement in multimodal AI, focusing on the integration of visual and linguistic information [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). These models aimed to bridge the gap between visual perception and language understanding, enabling tasks such as image captioning, visual question answering, and cross-modal retrieval .

Early vision-language models typically followed a two-stream architecture, with separate encoders for images and text, and a mechanism for fusing the encoded representations [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). These models often employed CNNs for image encoding and RNNs or transformers for text processing. The fusion of image and text features was typically done at the feature level, either by concatenation, element-wise multiplication, or more sophisticated methods such as bilinear pooling .

One of the earliest and most influential VLMs was CLIP (Contrastive Language-Image Pre-training), developed by OpenAI [(20)](https://dataloop.ai/blog/beyond-sight-decoding-the-multimodal-world-with-vision-language-models/). CLIP learns by analyzing massive datasets of image-text pairs, not directly generating text descriptions or images but excelling at understanding the relationship between them [(20)](https://dataloop.ai/blog/beyond-sight-decoding-the-multimodal-world-with-vision-language-models/). This makes CLIP a versatile tool for various tasks like image retrieval (finding images based on text descriptions) and zero-shot image classification [(20)](https://dataloop.ai/blog/beyond-sight-decoding-the-multimodal-world-with-vision-language-models/).

Another important development in this period was the introduction of the transformer architecture to vision-language tasks. The transformer, originally developed for natural language processing, dramatically improved the performance of image-text multimodal models, particularly in language understanding [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). Models such as BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) revolutionized the field of natural language processing and were subsequently applied to multimodal scenarios, such as ViLBERT (Visual and Language BERT) [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

ViLBERT and similar models like LXMERT added interaction layers between dual encoders to reason over relational embeddings, enabling them to process complex linguistic data and understand image content [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). These models could be applied to advanced visual quizzes and image-text matching tasks, demonstrating the power of transformer-based architectures for multimodal learning [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

### 3.2 Multimodal Pre-training Paradigms

The success of pre-training paradigms in natural language processing inspired similar approaches in multimodal learning. Vision-language pre-training (VLP) became the mainstream learning paradigm for vision, with the promise to learn universal transferable visual and vision-language representations .

The pretraining-finetuning paradigm represented a significant shift from task-specific architectures [(10)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.00389). In this approach, a model is first pre-trained on a large-scale multimodal dataset using self-supervised or contrastive objectives, and then fine-tuned on specific downstream tasks with smaller labeled datasets [(10)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.00389). This approach allows models to leverage the vast amounts of unlabeled multimodal data available on the web, improving their performance and generalization capabilities.

Several key pre-training objectives emerged during this period, including masked language modeling, masked image modeling, contrastive learning, and generative objectives [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). These objectives encouraged the model to learn meaningful cross-modal relationships and representations that could be adapted to various tasks [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857).

One of the most influential developments in multimodal pre-training was the introduction of the contrastive loss, which encourages the model to align image and text embeddings such that embeddings of matching image-text pairs are closer to each other than embeddings of non-matching pairs [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). This approach was successfully employed in models like CLIP and ALIGN, which demonstrated impressive zero-shot transfer capabilities [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857).

Another important development was the introduction of the "query former" (Q-former) architecture, which was used in models like BLIP-2 to connect visual models to large language models [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). This lightweight module allowed for efficient integration of visual information into language model-based systems, paving the way for the development of multimodal large language models [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

### 3.3 Advancements in Multimodal Architectures

As vision-language models evolved, researchers explored various architectural innovations to improve their performance and efficiency. These innovations included different approaches to modality-specific processing, cross-modal interaction, and model scaling [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

One significant architectural trend was the development of unified vision models for understanding and generation . These models aimed to combine the functionalities of specific-purpose multimodal models into a single architecture, using a unified model for various downstream computer vision and vision-language tasks . There were different levels of unification, from bridging vision and language by converting all closed-set vision tasks to open-set ones (such as CLIP, GLIP, OpenSeg) to unifying different vision-language understanding tasks across different granularity levels .

Another important architectural innovation was the development of encoder-decoder frameworks for multimodal tasks. These models typically employed an encoder to process the input (which could be an image, text, or both) and a decoder to generate the output in the desired modality . This approach was particularly effective for tasks like image captioning, where the goal is to generate a text description from an image, and for multimodal translation tasks .

The introduction of attention mechanisms was another crucial advancement in multimodal architectures. Attention allows the model to focus on relevant parts of the input when processing information from multiple modalities, improving the efficiency and accuracy of cross-modal interactions [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). Different types of attention mechanisms were developed, including cross-modal attention, which allows the model to attend to specific parts of one modality based on the content of another, and self-attention, which helps the model capture relationships within a single modality .

As models became more sophisticated, researchers also began exploring methods for parameter-efficient tuning of multimodal models. Techniques such as Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and its variants were applied to multimodal settings, allowing for efficient adaptation of large pre-trained models to specific tasks with minimal computational overhead [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). These techniques became particularly important with the rise of large language models in multimodal systems, as they enabled the integration of visual capabilities into existing language model frameworks without requiring full retraining [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

## 4. The Impact of Large Language Models on Multimodal AI

### 4.1 Integration of Vision and Language with LLMs

The development of large language models (LLMs) represented a paradigm shift in artificial intelligence, and their influence soon extended to the multimodal domain. LLMs, with their remarkable capabilities in natural language understanding and generation, provided a powerful foundation for integrating multiple modalities, particularly vision and language [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

The integration of vision with large language models typically follows one of two approaches: either projecting visual inputs into the language model's text space or modifying the language model architecture to accept visual inputs directly [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). The former approach, used in models like LLaVA, involves using a visual encoder to extract features from images and then projecting those features into the language model's input space, allowing the LLM to process them as if they were text tokens [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). This approach leverages the extensive knowledge and reasoning capabilities of the LLM while adding visual understanding through a lightweight adapter [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

The latter approach, exemplified by models like Kosmos-1 and Kosmos-2, involves modifying the language model architecture to handle interleaved visual and textual inputs [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These models typically employ a unified encoder-decoder architecture that can process both image patches and text tokens, allowing for more flexible and seamless integration of multiple modalities [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

The integration of vision and language in this way enables a wide range of new capabilities, from image captioning and visual question answering to more complex tasks like visual reasoning and instruction following [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). By leveraging the language model's existing understanding of language and world knowledge, these models can provide more contextually appropriate and coherent responses to multimodal inputs than earlier vision-language models [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

### 4.2 Multimodal Instruction Tuning

One of the key innovations that emerged with the integration of large language models and multimodal capabilities was the development of multimodal instruction tuning [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). This approach involves fine-tuning pre-trained multimodal models on a diverse set of instruction-following tasks, teaching the model to respond to natural language instructions that involve both text and visual inputs [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

Multimodal instruction tuning builds on the success of instruction tuning in language models, which has been shown to improve performance on unseen tasks and enhance alignment with human preferences [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). By extending this approach to multimodal settings, researchers have been able to create models that can follow a wide range of visual and linguistic instructions, from describing images and answering questions about visual content to performing complex tasks like generating code from wireframes or solving mathematical problems presented in images [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

Several influential models have adopted this approach. InstructBLIP, for example, builds on BLIP-2 by introducing a new instruction fine-tuning paradigm that demonstrates the extraction of more useful visual features by utilizing additional instructions [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). LLaVA, on the other hand, uses more concise connectors, such as linear layers or MLPs, to link visual models to large language models, achieving remarkable results with minimal architectural changes [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

The benefits of multimodal instruction tuning are significant. It allows models to generalize better to new tasks and domains, improves their ability to follow complex instructions, and enhances their alignment with human 意图 [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). This approach has become increasingly important as multimodal models have moved from research prototypes to practical applications, where the ability to understand and follow diverse instructions is essential [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

### 4.3 Multimodal Chain-of-Thought and Reasoning

The integration of large language models into multimodal systems has also enabled significant advancements in multimodal reasoning capabilities. One of the most important developments in this area has been the extension of the chain-of-thought (CoT) technique to multimodal settings, creating what is known as Multimodal Chain-of-Thought (MCoT) [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Chain-of-thought prompting, originally developed for language models, involves providing the model with intermediate reasoning steps when prompting it to solve a problem. This technique has been shown to significantly improve the performance of language models on complex reasoning tasks [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). Multimodal Chain-of-Thought extends this idea by incorporating visual and other non-linguistic elements into the reasoning process [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Early approaches to MCoT primarily focused on prompt-based adaptations, enabling models to produce step-by-step multimodal reasoning traces through carefully crafted instructions [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). Subsequent efforts enhanced the reasoning process itself, either by introducing structured decomposition of reasoning paths or by leveraging external tools and retrieval augmentation to expand inference capabilities beyond the model's static knowledge [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

However, most MCoT methods operate through short, reactive chains resembling fast, intuitive System-1 reasoning, which are effective for familiar or bounded problems but struggle with abstraction, compositionality, long-horizon reasoning, and adaptive planning [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). To address these limitations, recent research has turned toward System-2-inspired reasoning, emphasizing slower, deliberate, and methodologically structured cognitive processes [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

This shift has led to the development of Large Multimodal Reasoning Models (LMRMs), which extend MCoT along three critical dimensions: reasoning modalities, reasoning paradigms, and learning methods [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These models aim to support deeper, transferable, and cognitively grounded reasoning across multiple modalities [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Cross-modal reasoning, which leverages visual, auditory, and linguistic signals as joint substrates for inference, has enabled richer semantic grounding and more faithful information integration [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). Regarding reasoning paradigms, researchers have constructed longer, higher-quality chains and introduced generalized, methodologically guided reasoning strategies, allowing models to autonomously decompose complex tasks and apply transferable procedures across diverse contexts [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

From a learning method perspective, reinforcement learning-enhanced multimodal reasoning has gained increasing momentum. By incorporating agentic data, iterative feedback, and long-horizon optimization objectives, models like DeepSeek-R1 improve their planning, robustness, and adaptive generalization [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). This line of work has catalyzed the emergence of a new generation of R1-like models emphasizing scalable, methodologically grounded multimodal reasoning [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

## 5. Current State of Multimodal Large Language Models

### 5.1 Architecture and Design of Modern MLLMs

The current state of multimodal AI is dominated by Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), which represent the convergence of large language model technology with multimodal capabilities [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). These models are defined as LLM-based systems that can receive, process, and produce information in various modalities, including but not limited to text, images, videos, and audio [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

MLLMs differ from traditional multimodal approaches in two main aspects. First, they leverage the extensive scale and integrated knowledge of billion-parameter LLMs, a feature not available in previous multimodal models. Second, they adopt novel training paradigms, such as multimodal instruction tuning, to maximize their capabilities [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). The combination of advanced LLM architectures with innovative training methodologies enables MLLMs to achieve enhanced performance across a wide range of tasks [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

The architecture of modern MLLMs typically follows one of several patterns. The most common approach is to integrate a visual encoder with an LLM, either by projecting visual features into the language model's input space or by modifying the LLM architecture to accept visual inputs directly [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). For example, LLaVA utilizes a simple linear layer to project visual information into language space, endowing LLMs with the ability to perceive natural scenes [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

Other models, such as X-LLM and Chatbridge, use modal-specific modules to extract features for multiple modalities and employ modal-specific projection layers for multimodal alignment on a frozen LLM [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). However, these approaches often require complex training processes involving separate pre-training on unimodal data and joint instruction tuning on multimodal data [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

To address these challenges, X-InstructBLIP proposes a unified projection architecture (Q-former) for all modalities and collects large-scale, high-quality instruction tuning data to eliminate the need for unimodal pre-training [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). OneLLM takes this a step further by exploring parameter unification through the introduction of a unified encoder and projection module for a wide range of modalities [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

The general architecture of MLLMs typically includes several key components: a visual encoder (such as a CNN or Vision Transformer), a language model, and a mechanism for fusing or aligning the visual and linguistic representations [(8)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.16586). The visual encoder processes images or other visual inputs, converting them into feature vectors that can be understood by the language model [(8)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.16586). The language model then processes these features along with any textual inputs, generating appropriate responses in natural language [(8)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.16586).

Recent MLLMs have also incorporated advanced techniques such as adapter-based frameworks, which significantly reduce the parameter training burdens by at least 98.73% compared to full fine-tuning [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). These efficient tuning methods have made it practical to adapt large language models to multimodal tasks without requiring massive computational resources [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

### 5.2 Training Paradigms and Optimization Strategies

The training of multimodal large language models involves several distinct stages, each with its own challenges and optimization strategies [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). Understanding these training paradigms is essential for appreciating the technical breakthroughs that have enabled the development of modern MLLMs.

The first stage is data collection, which for MLLMs includes multimodal datasets that are no longer limited to text but can include images, audio, and/or videos [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). This allows MLLMs to learn cross-modal representations and capture relationships among multiple data modalities, leading to capabilities such as image captioning and visual question answering that are not achievable using standard LLMs [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

The second stage is data preprocessing, which for MLLMs is more complex than for text-only models. MLLMs need to conduct tasks such as image normalization, audio feature extraction, and aligning textual data with corresponding visual or auditory content [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). These additional steps are necessary to synchronize multimodal data and prepare it for the training process [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

The pre-training stage is where MLLMs learn cross-modal representations using objectives that leverage multimodal data [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). Unlike standard LLMs trained only on text, MLLMs utilize multimodal contrastive learning and other cross-modal objectives to capture relationships between text and other data types [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). This stage typically involves training on large-scale datasets with hundreds of millions or even billions of multimodal examples [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

Following pre-training, MLLMs undergo supervised fine-tuning on specific multimodal tasks using datasets with multimodal annotations [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). This stage adapts the general knowledge learned during pre-training to specific tasks, such as image captioning, visual question answering, or audio classification [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

Alignment to human preferences is another crucial stage in MLLM training. For MLLMs, this involves incorporating human feedback on multimodal outputs, such as evaluating the relevance of generated captions to images or the accuracy of responses in visual dialogues [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). Designing reward models that can assess multimodal content adds complexity compared to the text-only feedback in standard LLMs [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

Model optimization techniques are applied to enhance the efficiency and performance of MLLMs after training. These may include model compression, quantization, and distillation to reduce computational requirements and improve inference speed without notably degrading performance [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). These techniques are particularly important for deploying MLLMs in real-world applications where computational resources may be limited [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

Finally, the deployment stage involves integrating the trained MLLM into real-world applications. Key considerations include scalability, latency, and integration with existing systems [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). Frequent monitoring and maintenance are essential to ensure robust performance, with generated data from user interactions and feedback used to continuously improve the model over time [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585).

### 5.3 Capabilities and Applications of Modern MLLMs

Modern multimodal large language models have demonstrated a remarkable range of capabilities that extend far beyond those of earlier multimodal systems. These capabilities include advanced visual understanding, cross-modal reasoning, instruction following, and even the emergence of proto-theory of mind .

One of the most impressive capabilities of MLLMs is their ability to perform visual question answering (VQA), where the model interprets both an image and a related textual question to generate accurate answers [(23)](https://theblue.ai/blog/multimodal-models-ai/). This requires the model to simultaneously understand visual content and linguistic input, using attention mechanisms to balance the relevance of each data type [(23)](https://theblue.ai/blog/multimodal-models-ai/). MLLMs have achieved state-of-the-art performance on VQA benchmarks, demonstrating their ability to reason about complex visual scenes [(23)](https://theblue.ai/blog/multimodal-models-ai/).

Another significant capability is visual reasoning, which involves analyzing visual information and drawing logical conclusions based on that analysis. MLLMs can perform tasks such as identifying relationships between objects in an image, inferring the sequence of events in a series of images, or even predicting future events based on visual inputs [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). This type of reasoning is essential for applications in robotics, autonomous vehicles, and surveillance systems [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

MLLMs have also demonstrated remarkable abilities in multimodal content generation. Models like DALL-E and its successors can generate high-quality images based on textual descriptions, while newer models like Sora can generate minute-long videos with nuanced depictions of motion and interaction [(11)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2405.19334). These models have transformed creative industries, enabling new forms of digital art, design, and content creation [(11)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2405.19334).

In the realm of instruction following, MLLMs can now process complex instructions that involve multiple modalities. For example, an MLLM might be given an image and a text prompt asking it to describe the scene, identify specific objects, and explain how those objects relate to each other [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). The model can then generate a detailed response that integrates information from both modalities [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

Perhaps most intriguingly, recent research has shown that MLLMs can develop a proto-theory of mind (ToM), allowing them to make educated guesses about a person's feelings, intentions, and even create plausible backstories based on visual and textual context . This capability extends beyond sentiment analysis, paving the way for AI to predict and interpret human behavior more accurately .

The applications of these capabilities are vast and diverse. In healthcare, MLLMs can assist in medical diagnosis by analyzing medical images and patient histories simultaneously [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). In education, they can create personalized learning experiences that adapt to each student's needs using a combination of visual and textual materials . In customer service, MLLMs can provide more personalized and effective support by interpreting both verbal and visual cues from customers [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

MLLMs are also transforming creative industries, with applications in content creation, design, and entertainment [(11)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2405.19334). They can generate visual content based on textual descriptions, create music from visual inputs, or even produce entire multimedia stories that combine text, images, and audio [(11)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2405.19334).

In the realm of autonomous systems, MLLMs are enhancing the capabilities of robots and self-driving vehicles by enabling them to better understand their environment through multiple sensors and make more informed decisions based on that understanding [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). They can integrate visual data from cameras with lidar, radar, and other sensors, along with textual instructions or maps, to navigate complex environments safely and efficiently [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

## 6. Key Technological Breakthroughs in Multimodal AI Evolution

### 6.1 Deep Learning Architecture Innovations

The evolution of multimodal AI has been driven by several key architectural innovations in deep learning. These innovations have transformed the way multimodal information is processed, fused, and utilized by AI systems [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

One of the most significant architectural breakthroughs was the development of the transformer architecture [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). Originally introduced for natural language processing, the transformer's self-attention mechanism revolutionized multimodal learning by allowing models to efficiently capture complex relationships between different modalities [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). The transformer's ability to process inputs of variable length and attend to different parts of the input with varying degrees of focus made it particularly suitable for multimodal tasks where the alignment between modalities is crucial [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

The adaptation of transformers for vision tasks led to the development of Vision Transformers (ViTs), which process images as sequences of patches rather than using convolutional layers . ViTs demonstrated that transformers could achieve state-of-the-art performance on image classification and other visual tasks, opening the door to unified transformer-based architectures for both vision and language .

The introduction of the encoder-decoder framework was another crucial architectural innovation . This framework allows models to process inputs in one modality (such as an image) and generate outputs in another modality (such as text), making it particularly suitable for tasks like image captioning, video description, and multimodal translation .

Modular neural network architectures also played an important role in the evolution of multimodal AI. Neural Module Networks (NMN) dynamically assemble task-specific modules to compose visual and textual features, replacing static fusion [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). This approach allows models to adapt their architecture to the specific demands of each task, improving flexibility and performance [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Attention mechanisms, which had a transformative impact on natural language processing, also revolutionized multimodal learning [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). Different types of attention mechanisms were developed for multimodal tasks, including cross-modal attention (which allows the model to attend to specific parts of one modality based on another), hierarchical co-attention (which aligns question semantics with image regions hierarchically), and stacked attention networks (which modularize reasoning via iterative attention hops over visual features) [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

The development of memory-augmented architectures was another significant breakthrough. Models such as Dynamic Memory Networks integrate memory modules for multi-episode reasoning over sequential inputs, while MAC employs a memory-augmented control unit for iterative compositional reasoning [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These architectures enable more sophisticated reasoning and planning capabilities in multimodal systems [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Finally, the introduction of Mixture of Experts (MoE) architectures has been a recent breakthrough in scaling multimodal models. These architectures incorporate multiple "expert" networks for each modality, allowing the model to select the most appropriate expert for each input [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). MoE-based models like MoME (which combines visual expert mixture and language expert mixture) have demonstrated improved performance and efficiency on multimodal tasks [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

### 6.2 Representation Learning and Cross-Modal Alignment

The ability to learn effective representations that capture the relationships between different modalities has been a central challenge in multimodal AI, and several key breakthroughs in this area have driven the field forward [(10)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.00389).

One of the earliest approaches to cross-modal representation learning was kernel canonical correlation analysis (KCCA), which projects image and sentence features into a common space by learning projections [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). This method allowed for the comparison and alignment of features from different modalities, but it was limited by its linear nature and inability to capture complex relationships [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

The development of deep neural networks enabled more powerful approaches to cross-modal representation learning. Early methods attempted bidirectional mapping between images and text descriptions using CNNs and RNNs [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). These models learned to encode images and text into a shared feature space, allowing for cross-modal retrieval and other tasks [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

Contrastive learning emerged as a powerful technique for cross-modal alignment, particularly with the development of models like CLIP and ALIGN [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). These models use a contrastive loss to align image and text embeddings such that embeddings of matching pairs are closer to each other than embeddings of non-matching pairs [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). This approach allows models to learn meaningful cross-modal relationships from large-scale, noisy image-text pairs mined from the web [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857).

The introduction of pre-training paradigms significantly improved the quality of cross-modal representations. Models like BERT, which were originally developed for natural language processing, were adapted to multimodal settings through techniques like masked language modeling, masked image modeling, and multimodal contrastive learning [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). These pre-training objectives encourage the model to learn representations that capture both intra-modal and cross-modal relationships [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857).

Another important breakthrough was the development of techniques for aligning different levels of abstraction between modalities. For example, the multi-granularity hybrid visual encoding framework MaVEn combines discrete visual symbol sequences representing abstract, coarse-grained semantic concepts with traditional continuous representation sequences that simulate fine-grained features [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). This combination enhances the model's ability to understand visual information in images [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

The MoVA framework takes this a step further by incorporating coarse-grained context-aware expert routing and fine-grained expert fusion [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). This framework adaptively routes and fuses visual experts for specific tasks through a coarse-to-fine mechanism, thereby mitigating the bias of the CLIP visual encoder and enhancing the model's ability to understand and process diverse image content [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

The development of alignment techniques that go beyond simple feature matching has also been crucial. Models like BLIP introduce the image-text transformer module Q-former and employ vision-language pre-training with contrastive objectives to reason via bootstrapped alignment [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3). This approach allows the model to learn more accurate and robust cross-modal relationships [(15)](https://arxiv.org/html/2309.15857v3).

Recent advances in alignment techniques have focused on improving efficiency and scalability. For example, adapter-based frameworks like those used in PathWeave enable efficient modality alignment and collaboration with minimal computational overhead [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). These techniques have made it practical to train and deploy large multimodal models at scale [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

### 6.3 Efficient Training and Fine-Tuning Techniques

As multimodal models have grown in size and complexity, the development of efficient training and fine-tuning techniques has become increasingly important. Several key breakthroughs in this area have made it possible to train and adapt large multimodal models more efficiently [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

One of the most significant breakthroughs was the development of parameter-efficient fine-tuning techniques. These techniques allow researchers to adapt pre-trained models to specific tasks with minimal computational resources by only updating a small subset of the model's parameters [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) was one of the first and most influential of these techniques, reducing the trainable parameters through low-rank matrix decomposition [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

The success of LoRA promoted the development of parameter-efficient transfer learning for MLLMs and unimodal continual learning approaches [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). These techniques have been particularly valuable for multimodal models, where the computational costs of full fine-tuning can be prohibitive [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

Adapter-based frameworks represent another important advancement in efficient training [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). These frameworks introduce small adapter modules into the model architecture, which can be trained while keeping the rest of the model parameters frozen [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). This approach significantly reduces the number of parameters that need to be trained, making it possible to adapt large models to new tasks with minimal computational resources [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

The Adapter-in-Adapter (AnA) framework takes this idea further by incorporating both unimodal and cross-modal adapters for efficient modality alignment and collaboration [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). This framework allows MLLMs to continually evolve on modalities for X-modal reasoning by leveraging the concept of Continual Learning and developing an incremental training strategy atop pre-trained MLLMs [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

Another important breakthrough was the development of techniques for efficient multimodal data processing. For example, the Adaptive Multimodal Data Augmentation framework SLUDA generates fine-grained data, optimizes the utilization of unlabeled data, and employs adaptive selection strategies and dynamic threshold adjustments [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). This approach addresses the issues of insufficient labeled data and the underutilization of unlabeled data in multimodal learning [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

The development of efficient cross-modal attention mechanisms has also been crucial for scaling multimodal models. Techniques like the Cantor framework integrate visual inputs with logical reasoning and leverage the advanced cognitive functions of MLLMs [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). By acting as a multifaceted expert, it directly acquires higher-level information, thereby improving decision-making quality [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

The introduction of curriculum learning strategies has further improved the efficiency of multimodal training. These strategies involve training the model on easier tasks before moving on to more complex ones, which can lead to faster convergence and better overall performance [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). For example, the Bloom framework uses bidirectional modality transformation and adaptive cross-modal fusion, introducing a curriculum learning strategy to enhance training efficiency and multilingual recognition performance [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

Finally, the development of techniques for incremental learning and modality expansion has been a significant breakthrough. PathWeave, for example, is a flexible and scalable framework with modal-Path sWitching and ExpAnsion abilities that enables MLLMs to continually EVolve on modalities for X-modal reasoning [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178). This framework allows MLLMs to expand to new modalities using unimodal data without executing joint-modal pre-training [(1)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.20178).

### 6.4 Integration of External Tools and Knowledge

The integration of external tools and knowledge sources has become increasingly important as multimodal models have evolved, allowing them to access information beyond their pre-trained knowledge and perform more complex tasks [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

One significant breakthrough in this area was the development of retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) techniques for multimodal models [(4)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.01763). These techniques allow models to retrieve relevant information from external knowledge bases during inference, supplementing their pre-trained knowledge with up-to-date or specialized information [(4)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.01763). RAG has now evolved to handle a wide range of data types by lending the power of multimodal models [(4)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.01763).

For example, RAGAR (Retrieval-Augmented Generation with Adaptive Retrieval) proposes CoRAG and ToRAG to support political fact-checking through retrieval of multimodal evidence [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). Chain-of-Action retrieves information from heterogeneous sources through configurable reasoning chains [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). KAM-CoT incorporates knowledge graphs as external knowledge sources to augment multimodal reasoning [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

AR-MCTS integrates dynamic step-wise retrieval with Monte Carlo Tree Search, enabling MLLMs to access relevant knowledge at each reasoning step and automatically generate high-quality reasoning annotations [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These approaches enhance the reasoning capabilities of MLLMs by providing them with access to external knowledge sources that can supplement their pre-trained knowledge [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Another important development was the integration of multimodal models with specialized tools for specific tasks. For example, some works incorporate external textual-enhancing tools that guide, structure, or refine the overall reasoning process through language [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). L3GO employs GPT-4 with Chain-of-Thought prompting to produce explicit textual reasoning steps, which guide 3D mesh construction in a Blender environment, aided by ControlNet for visual grounding [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

HYDRA and Det-CoT leverage large language models not only as planners but also as dynamic instruction generators, error diagnosers, and reasoning controllers [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These models interact with visual foundation models (e.g., BLIP2, LLaVA) and reinforcement learning agents, using textual prompts and feedback to iteratively improve visual understanding and decision-making [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). Both systems integrate a State Memory Bank to maintain dialogue history or prior instructions, enabling incremental CoT reasoning via textual modulation [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

The development of frameworks for chaining multiple tools and models together has also been crucial. For example, the Octopus framework achieves parallel recognition of object queries at the lower LLM layers and passes the results to the top LLM layers for sequential understanding, thereby improving the efficiency and accuracy of MLLMs [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

The Wings framework introduces additional modules and mechanisms to compensate for attention shifts, allowing the model to effectively process visual information while maintaining focus on textual information [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). These types of frameworks enable more flexible and powerful multimodal reasoning by combining the strengths of different models and tools [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

Finally, the development of techniques for knowledge distillation in multimodal settings has been an important breakthrough. The Tiny-Large collaborative training framework CTVLMs leverages knowledge distillation and multimodal alignment to enable large models to transfer knowledge to smaller models [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). This approach achieves a dual improvement in both performance and efficiency [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

## 7. Future Directions and Challenges in Multimodal AI

### 7.1 Technical Challenges and Research Frontiers

Despite the significant progress in multimodal AI, several technical challenges remain that need to be addressed to advance the field further [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). These challenges span various aspects of multimodal learning, from representation learning and cross-modal alignment to computational efficiency and generalization [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

One of the most fundamental challenges is achieving precise and efficient alignment across different modalities—such as vision, language, and motion [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Despite significant advances in multimodal models, developing methods to robustly fuse and align these modalities in real-time, particularly for embodied tasks, remains a critical research focus [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). For example, both current visual-language models and vision-audio models depend on effective alignment of data from diverse modalities, and without proper alignment, the accuracy and efficiency of the response are likely to degrade [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Computational resources and efficiency present another major challenge. MLLMs demand significant computational resources and storage, and improving computational efficiency while preserving high performance is essential [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Advances in model compression, distributed computing, and hardware acceleration will be crucial in addressing these challenges [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). At present, most models have vast numbers of parameters, and both training and inference processes rely on high-performance GPUs, which are time-intensive and expensive [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Generalization across domains is another significant challenge. While multimodal models have demonstrated impressive performance on specific benchmarks or within particular domains, their ability to generalize across diverse contexts or tasks remains limited [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Researchers must explore methods to enhance the transferability and adaptability of these models for real-world applications [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). For instance, current embodied large models are typically categorized into perception models, interaction models, and navigation models, with the scope of tasks they can address being relatively fixed and their generalization ability remaining suboptimal [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Handling temporal and sequential information is another area that requires further research. Embodied models must manage dynamic, real-time data and sequential interactions, which adds complexity to multimodal learning [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Developing models that can effectively process and reason about temporal sequences across multiple modalities is essential for applications such as video understanding, robotics, and human-computer interaction [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Scalability is a persistent challenge as multimodal models continue to grow in size and complexity. Training and deploying large multimodal models requires substantial computational resources, and finding ways to scale these models efficiently is crucial [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). This includes developing more efficient training algorithms, optimizing model architectures for scalability, and leveraging distributed computing resources effectively [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Robustness and reliability are also important research frontiers. Multimodal models must be able to handle noisy, ambiguous, and incomplete inputs, as well as adversarial examples [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Developing techniques to improve the robustness of these models and ensure their reliable performance across diverse conditions is essential for real-world applications [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

### 7.2 Emerging Trends and Opportunities

Several emerging trends are shaping the future of multimodal AI, creating new opportunities for research and application development [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). These trends include the development of embodied multimodal models, the integration of multimodal learning with robotics and autonomous systems, and the expansion of multimodal capabilities to new modalities beyond vision and language [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Embodied multimodal models (EMLMs) represent a rapidly growing area of research that focuses on integrating multimodal perception with physical interaction [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). These models aim to develop AI systems that can perceive, reason, and act in the physical world, combining visual, auditory, tactile, and other sensory inputs with motor control [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). The development of EMLMs has surged, but it still faces numerous challenges, including cross-modal alignment, computational resources and efficiency, and generalization across domains [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Another emerging trend is the integration of multimodal models with robotics and autonomous systems. This integration enables robots to better understand their environment through multiple sensors and make more informed decisions based on that understanding [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). For example, the Meteor model, based on the Mamba architecture, enhances the comprehension and response capabilities of large language and vision models through multifaceted reasoning [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). This type of integration is opening up new possibilities for robotics applications, from autonomous navigation to complex manipulation tasks [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

The expansion of multimodal capabilities to new modalities is another exciting trend. While most research has focused on vision and language, there is growing interest in integrating other modalities such as audio, haptics, olfactory, and even temporal information [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608). For example, the Bloom framework uses bidirectional modality transformation and adaptive cross-modal fusion to pretrain a Visual Speech Recognition (VSR) model with visual and speech units [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887). This expansion is creating new opportunities for applications in healthcare, environmental monitoring, and human-computer interaction [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

The development of more sophisticated reasoning capabilities in multimodal models is another important trend. Large Multimodal Reasoning Models (LMRMs) are emerging as a new class of models capable of deeper, transferable, and cognitively grounded reasoning across multiple modalities [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These models extend Multimodal Chain-of-Thought (MCoT) along three critical dimensions—reasoning modalities, reasoning paradigms, and learning methods [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

The integration of multimodal models with external knowledge sources and tools is also becoming increasingly important. Techniques like retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) are being extended to multimodal settings, allowing models to access external knowledge during inference [(4)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.01763). Additionally, frameworks like HYDRA and Det-CoT leverage large language models not only as planners but also as dynamic instruction generators, error diagnosers, and reasoning controllers [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Finally, there is growing interest in developing more efficient and scalable approaches to multimodal learning. This includes advances in model compression, efficient training techniques, and hardware optimization [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). For example, the Flextron framework supports adaptive subnetwork selection by using routers to choose different sub-models or subnetworks, addressing the deployment challenges of multimodal large models in resource-constrained environments [(2)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.01887).

### 7.3 Ethical and Societal Implications

As multimodal AI continues to advance, it raises important ethical and societal questions that need to be addressed [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). These include issues related to bias and fairness, privacy and data protection, transparency and accountability, and the potential impact on employment and society [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Bias and fairness are significant concerns in multimodal AI, as these models are trained on large datasets that may reflect and perpetuate existing societal biases [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). For example, visual recognition systems have been shown to exhibit racial and gender biases, which can have serious consequences in applications such as hiring, law enforcement, and healthcare [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Developing techniques to identify and mitigate these biases is essential to ensure that multimodal AI systems are fair and equitable [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Privacy and data protection are also important considerations. Multimodal models often require large amounts of personal data, including images, audio recordings, and other sensitive information [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Ensuring that this data is collected, stored, and used in a way that respects individuals' privacy rights is crucial [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). This includes developing techniques for privacy-preserving data collection and processing, such as federated learning and differential privacy [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Transparency and accountability present significant challenges in multimodal AI, particularly as models become more complex and their decision-making processes more opaque [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Understanding how a model arrives at a particular decision is difficult enough in unimodal systems, but it becomes even more challenging in multimodal systems that integrate information from multiple sources [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Developing techniques for explaining and auditing multimodal models is essential to ensure their responsible deployment [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

The potential impact on employment and society is another important consideration. Multimodal AI has the potential to automate many tasks that currently require human judgment and expertise, which could lead to significant changes in the job market [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). At the same time, these technologies also create new opportunities for innovation and economic growth [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Developing policies and programs to support workers through these transitions is essential [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Additionally, there are concerns about the potential misuse of multimodal AI technologies. For example, deepfakes and other forms of synthetic media created using multimodal models could be used to spread misinformation or manipulate public opinion [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Developing techniques to detect and mitigate these risks is crucial to ensure the responsible development and deployment of multimodal AI [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Finally, there are questions about the distribution of benefits from multimodal AI. These technologies require significant resources to develop and deploy, which may limit access to them [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Ensuring that the benefits of multimodal AI are distributed fairly across society, rather than being concentrated in the hands of a few organizations or individuals, is an important societal challenge [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

## 8. Conclusion

The evolution of multimodal models from early visual representations to current multimodal large language models represents one of the most significant advancements in artificial intelligence over the past decade . This journey has been marked by a series of remarkable technological breakthroughs, from the early days of handcrafted features and modular systems to the sophisticated transformer-based architectures and large multimodal reasoning models of today [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857).

Early multimodal research focused on combining simple visual and auditory inputs for specific tasks, such as audio-visual speech recognition [(12)](https://www.twelvelabs.io/blog/what-is-multimodal-ai). These early systems were limited in their capabilities and required task-specific engineering to function effectively [(12)](https://www.twelvelabs.io/blog/what-is-multimodal-ai). The introduction of deep learning techniques revolutionized multimodal AI, enabling the development of more flexible and powerful models that could learn to integrate information from multiple modalities .

The rise of vision-language models represented a significant milestone in this evolution, as researchers began to focus on bridging the gap between visual perception and language understanding [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). Models like CLIP and ALIGN demonstrated the power of contrastive learning for cross-modal alignment, while transformer-based architectures enabled more sophisticated reasoning about relationships between visual and linguistic information [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857).

The integration of large language models with multimodal capabilities marked another major turning point [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). These multimodal large language models (MLLMs) leverage the extensive knowledge and reasoning capabilities of LLMs while adding visual understanding through lightweight adapters or modified architectures [(9)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.16585). This integration has enabled a wide range of new capabilities, from advanced visual question answering to complex multimodal reasoning and instruction following [(5)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2410.05608).

The development of multimodal instruction tuning and chain-of-thought reasoning techniques has further enhanced the capabilities of these models, enabling them to perform complex tasks across multiple modalities [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921). These techniques have paved the way for the development of large multimodal reasoning models (LMRMs) that can engage in deeper, more sophisticated forms of reasoning across multiple modalities [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).

Looking forward, the field of multimodal AI faces several important challenges and opportunities [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Technical challenges include achieving precise cross-modal alignment, improving computational efficiency, enhancing generalization across domains, and handling temporal and sequential information [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Emerging trends such as embodied multimodal models, integration with robotics, expansion to new modalities, and enhanced reasoning capabilities are creating exciting new research directions [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

Ethical and societal considerations are also becoming increasingly important as multimodal AI systems become more powerful and widespread [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336). Ensuring that these systems are fair, transparent, and accountable, protecting privacy and data rights, and addressing the potential impact on employment and society are all critical challenges that need to be addressed [(7)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2502.15336).

In conclusion, the evolution of multimodal models has transformed artificial intelligence, enabling systems that can perceive and understand the world in ways that were previously unimaginable . From early attempts to combine simple modalities to the sophisticated multimodal large language models of today, this journey has been driven by innovation, creativity, and a deep understanding of the challenges involved in integrating information from multiple sources [(14)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2309.15857). As we move forward, continued research and development in this area will undoubtedly lead to even more powerful and capable systems that can perceive, reason, and interact with the world in increasingly human-like ways [(3)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.04921).
